title: Turkmenistan - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: Arrests: Around 25 January 2021 (week of), in Lebap region the police detained dozens of bearded men on suspicion of involvement in Wahabi sect. They were questioned in the police station and had to shave their beards before being released. [coded to Turkmenabat with GP2]

On 21 December 2020, around 50 women gathered outside the regional administration building in Mary to tell the authorities that there was no flour, bread and drinking water in their villages. The officials did not come out to speak to the women but promised that they would work on the issue. [size=about 50]

On 16 October 2020, about 100 protesters, mostly women, in Turkmenabat (Lebap) gathered at the town administration's office, demanding the authorities to renew their driving license and give them the right to drive. [size=about 100]

On 4 October 2020, flea market traders organized a protest in Turkmenabat and marched to the local administration building, demanding authorities to solve the case of the closure of the flea market by the police. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Turkmenistan (2006-) Border service

On 30 September 2020, an exchange of fire between an Afghan armed group and Turkmen border guards occurred on the Turkmen-Afghan border, near an area for which the 7th outpost of Kerki (Lebap) border detachment is responsible. No one was injured on the Turkmen side. There is no information about Afghan casualties mentioned by the source.

On 25 September 2020, people gathered in front of the regional prosecutor's office in Balkanabat, after the local bank delayed its service to provide to their clients' cash from the ATM. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, about 1000 parents, students and teachers protested at the school N64 in Ashgabat city against shut down of the Russian language program, loss of jobs for Russian language teachers and transfer of students to other schools days prior to the start of the new school season. School administration called in for police help after which about 25 policemen dispersed the protestors and detained two people for recording demonstration on their smartphones. [size=about 1000]

On 28 August 2020, a scuffle broke out between produce sellers and police at the produce market on Mollanepes street in the town of Mary after police raided the market which triggered resistance from an unknown number of sellers resulting in detentions. [size=unknown]

On 12 August 2020, hundreds of residents from rural districts demonstrated outside the Daikhan and Senagat banks blocking main Mollanepes street in Mary city after representatives of the banks refused to assist them with cash withdrawals. Police were called in to maintain public safety when demonstrators briefly scuffled with policemen. [size=hundreds]

On 12 August 2020, a 70-year-old woman journalist was physically assaulted by police officer at the back-to-school flea market near Gulistan shopping center of Ashgabat city, after she took pictures on her camera for a photo story. Policemen claimed that taking photos were forbidden in that space.

On 2 July 2020, the government of Turkmenistan imposed restrictions to prevent a potential outbreak of coronavirus in the country's capital Ashgabat and across the nation. Shopping malls, markets, parks, theaters and sports venues are prohibited to operate from 2 July until 1 August 2020.

On 18 June 2020, people standing in line in front of a the grocery shop in Bayramaly town of Mary region attacked policemen who were there to regulate the crowd. This was in response to police's detainment of one of the persons who criticized the authorities and the way the current food crises is regulated in the country. [size=unknown]
Police Forces of Turkmenistan (2006-) Border service
Police Forces of Turkmenistan (2006-) Border service

Around 1 June 2020 (beginning of month), a consript border serviceman has been hospitalized in Ashgabat city after sustaining routine physical abuse and assault at the hands of officers and border guards at the Garry-gala border post (near Magtymguly) in Balkan region near the border with Iran. The soldier died in the hospital.

On 13 May 2020, several hundreds of people protested in Turkmenabad, Lebap condemning the inaction of the authorities following the hurricane and heavy rain that hit the province in the past two weeks, killing about 30 people. Many residents complained about living in poor conditions and having scarce food and water. The local authorities were reported to arrive at the scene to talk to protesters and promised to provide more assistance and offer private home owners low-cost loans. [size=several hundreds]

On 3 April 2020, approximately 30 residents, mostly women, of the villages in the close vicinity to Mary blocked the highway and gathered before the regional administration building as a protest against the ongoing food shortage - among others flour, vegetable oil and similar basic products. This food shortage is allegedly caused by the restriction of the transport communication between the regions and cities in Turkmenistan, imposed by the government in the last weeks as a preventive measure against the coronavirus. [size=approximately 30]

Starting on 4 March 2020, in order to prevent the spread of coronavirus, Turkmenistan government restricted entry to the capital city Ashgabat, the movement of citizens between the provinces was indefinitely limited. For travel from one region to another, residents required the necessary permission and a certificate confirming their lack of COVID-19.On March 20, 2020 Turkmenistan's authorities have restricted movement of the people between all country's provinces. The permission is granted in exceptional cases and only on the basis of a medical certificate confirming absence of the 'coronavirus'.
On 2 April 2020, the source reports ongoing arrests of people in Lebap province, for mentioning 'coronavirus' in their conversations. The arrested are kept in custody for about 10 days at least.

On 8 October 2019, law enforcers in Turkmenabat reportedly detained and tortured a man in order to obtain his confession to a theft. The torture lasted for several days; then the man was in such poor condition, that he was released to his family. Then he was immediately transferred to a hospital, but reportedly the law enforcers pushed the doctors not to treat him and not to report his injuries as a result of torture; in the end, reportedly, the hospital sent the man home.

Other: On 1 October 2019, about 70 soldiers located at a military base in Serhetabat were transferred to hospital facilities in Ashgabat with wounds of various degrees of severity, claimed witnesses and sources of RFE/RL. This happened shortly after armed clashes were recently reported from the borders with Afghanistan. More precise information about the soldiers or the armed clash could not be obtained from official sources.

Around 30 September 2019 (as reported), servicemen of the border military units located especially near Kerki district in the Lebap province were frequently targeted from the Afghan side of the border. An unspecified number of them suffered various injuries and had to be treated in local hospitals. The government of Turkmenistan does not usually provide information regarding border clashes; reports came from families of the wounded or deceased.

Arrests: Around 27 September 2019 (as reported), law enforcers in Mary detained a large number of homeless residents of the city and transferred them to temporary detention facilities. Such measures were applied reportedly prior the upcoming national Independence Day. The exact number of detainees could not be confirmed.

During the week of 23 September, at least two soldiers of the Turkmen military forces from the Balkan and Mary regions [coded to Balkanabat] were wounded in an armed clash with an unidentified armed group or groups close to the border with Afghanistan.

As reported on 17 September, in the beginning of the month, four conscripts of the Turkmen army were killed. According to the report, all deaths were caused by beating and violence within the military structures. The incident took place in Shagal, Lebap province. [conscripts coded as off-duty]

On 1 September 2019, a conscript of the military forces of Turkmenistan reportedly died of severe beatings at the base in Kerki, Lebap province. The perpetrators, assumed to be military officers, have been detained. [conscript coded as off-duty]

On 20 August 2019, a conscript of the military forces of Turkmenistan died after a severe beating on the military base in Balkanabat, believed to have been perpetrated by an officer. [conscript coded as off-duty]

Since 20 July, capacity and speed of the internet in Turkmenistan [coded to Ashgabat] deteriorated significantly and even also most of tools like VPN stopped working. Activists linked the measure, allegedly imposed by the government, to the recent rumors about death of the President and their effort to stop spreading of these news on social networks.
Police Forces of Turkmenistan (2006-) Prison Guards

Around 16 July 2019 (as reported), death of a teacher and an alleged follower of Fetullah Gullen, was reported. According to the anonymous source from the government and RFE/RL, his death was caused by torture in the Bayramaly prison facility. According to the authorities, he died because of hepatitis. [coded according to the civilian's version]

On 26 June 2019, the death of a conscript of the Turkmen military forces was reported by his relatives. The soldier was based in Serhetabat and according to military officials he allegedly died on 25 June because of poisoning, but the relatives reported his internal organs were removed and several bullet-like holes were found in his back. Authorities refused to comment these injuries. [coded as military forces being shot by unidentified armed group]

Arrests: Around 29 May 2019 (as reported), a lengthy extensive raid against migrants was conducted in Ashgabat. Police forces were reportedly detaining dozens of unregistered migrants, primarily women, without any explanation, and forced them to undergo medical examination. Those with viruses or diseases were arrested and transferred at least 70 individuals to special detention facilities.
On 29 May 2019, mothers of the graduate students in Dasoguz protested against school authorities, accusing them of illegal charges imposed on school diplomas and graduation party. [size=about 15]

On 9 May 2019, a crowd of women attacked Turkmen official in Dasoguz district. According to the report women accused the official of flour shortage. The official was not injured and managed to escape and sent the police to interrogate the women afterwards. [size=no report]

On 19 March 2019, four women attacked a policeman in Ashgabat, because he wanted to revoke their driver licenses, although they reportedly did not violate any traffic rule. Seizing licenses from women in Turkmenistan has been reported many times so far. [size=4]

Since 30 November, a pensioner disappeared. After publishing video messages where he complained about the illegal confiscation of his apartment, the pensioner was repeatedly threatened by law enforcement officers. On 27 November, he could not attend an appointment at the prosecutor's office and was told that he will be picked up by law enforcement with handcuffs. [coded to the version of the civilian] [coded to Ashgabat]

Around 9 July 2018, the Police Forces of Turkmenistan dispersed a riot at the local bazaar in Ashgabat as a reaction to the sudden increase in prices. People were outraged, trying to break into the stores and shouting criticism against the head of the state and his policy. At least 5 of the rioters were detained by the police and taken to the police department. [size=at least 5]

Around 13 June 2018, an armed clash happened between military forces of Turkmenistan and an unidentified armed group from Afghanistan at the Turkmen-Afghan Border near Serhetabat. As a result of the clash, about 25 Turkmen soldiers were killed at unidentified locations [coded to Serhetabat].
On 6th June 2018, in Ashgabat, Turkmenistan government restricted right of visa-free travel for citizens of Kazakhstan's Mangistau region.

As reported on 22 October 2019, an LGBT citizen of Turkmenistan was arrested and beaten by the Turkmenistan police in Ashgabat. The reason behind this violent act is allegedly adherence to the LGBT. The exact date of the event is unknown, the sequence of events place it between January and September 2018 [coded to May 2018].

On 6 March 2018, a violent demonstration took place in Mary settlement, Turkmenistan. Locals demanded more flour to be distributed among them by the local authorities. The head of the village council was beaten, then the locals broke into the local store and took the flour themselves. Intervention of police forces was not reported. [size=no report]

On 6 March 2018, female residents of Mary settlement, Turkmenistan, blocked the road, protesting against unequal distribution of flour among citizens. Later they peacefully left the place. (Another protest of other residents happened the very same day). [size=no report]

bites.bite: The largest admin1 is Mary with 12 reports followed by Ashgabat with 11 reports.
